Anonymous Sun 10 Dec 2017 04:56:52 No.12941456 Report
Quoted By:
>>12941304
I guess it depends on what you want the worldbuilding to be used for. As long as the action is focused on the protagonist, you can trickle in details about the world only as they're needed. There's no sense in wasting time establishing a huge backstory or world history if the current scene only pertains to an anon and his immediate surroundings. If you REALLY need to set the stage for something to come in the near future, that's when some kind of exposition dump might be useful.

Hopefully that's what you were asking.
Anonymous

Anonymous Sun 10 Dec 2017 05:18:44 No.12941857 Report
Quoted By: >>12942137 >>12942141
Wheresmysocks, just read most of Time of the Season but I had to stop because there is one major flaw with your writing style and that is the pacing.

There is such a thing as too much attention to detail and when you got too much it makes getting through even portions of the story a chore because there is too much focus on minutiae and not enough on the important details.

Like do we really need a description of the whole process of Anon taking a canoe out on the lake? Or is it really important to describe him going through ever step in lighting a fire? Or Zoey cooking three times in a row with descriptions of what shes cooking?

This sort of stuff grinds immersion to a halt by destroying the flow of the narrative. Next time you write a story try to trim the fat a bit and focus on the important details which move the story forward.
Anonymous
  • Post
  • Report

Anonymous Sun 10 Dec 2017 05:52:33 No.12942477 Report
Quoted By:
>>12942148
Turkey Shoot let me have Doug's mind, and that makes my job a lot easier. That's kind of a crutch though, and I ought to be able to do without it. Part of me thinks green is better practice all around, even for the projects I'm taking seriously/showing to publishers. Green forces me to do a lot of things I'm not very good at or comfortable doing.
>Rapid pace
>Lean introspection/monologue
>Second person limited present tense eccentricities

If I look at TS, the most effective part is probably the very end, where I'm not doing anything I couldn't in a green. I think figuring out what I'm doing right and wrong in DP could be a boon to everything I work on. Guess I'll keep with greens for now for the sake of what they make me practice doing, if nothing else, and use longform for oneshots.

My biggest weaknesses are being slow to plot, and light on conflict. Neither TS or early DP really have this problem though, and I'm revising 5 of DP to recapture the success of earlier chapters. Using Alfa for reference, in part. He and I have fairly different styles, but he's a more expedient storyteller than I am. HPoF manages to be comfy and still have a fairly immediate conflict. I figure I need to teach myself into being able to do that kind of thing, if in some cases with higher stakes

Anonymous Sun 10 Dec 2017 11:49:11 No.12945994 Report
Quoted By: >>12946149
>>12941304
Hobo here.
My opinion towards posting first drafts is NEVER EVER. Seriously, that shit is a cardinal sin. However, once upon a time I workes in education so holding myself to that might just be me having a stick up my ass.
Write first draft, reread it, add in any missing details and/or fix clunky wordinh in the second draft, reread, and repeat until you're satisfied.

Introduce world details as they come up, and only expand if they're relevant. Don't blow your expositional load all over the reader about the local subway system if it'll never be visited in the story, after all. For example: >>12945701
I wrote 400 words about how ITEMs work in that document. Once I put that information into a story, I'll be looking to condense that down into only the most relevant parts, skipping some things I decided were 'canon' entirely from mention because either the characters wouldn't know that or just wouldn't relate to the scene on hand. Believe it or not, the average reader will realize the difference between learning a little bit more about the world via character interaction, context, and slang usage, and when they're being force fed line after line about something that could be introduced in a far more nuanced and organic manner.

>>12945880
Lord yes. Imagine a crime novellist not knowing how due process works, or a book about firefighters describing them diving into burning buildings without mentioning their essential gear like O2 tanks and face masks. A fuck up like that results in angry and/or disappointed letters from readers.

I've just thought up a story where some video game collector NEET found a rare and expensive piece of gaming hardware, but it's sold way up in the mountains at this mom 'n pop store. The listing's on the internet, and he can't tell if it's a trap or not, but it's within such a good price he can't help but go outside to get it. When he gets there, he's greeted by a low-light environment that doesn't resemble a game store at all, but there are of course games and rare hardware/accessories there. Turns out, it used to be a shrine of a local deity, and the store owner is a real bombshell ninetails that looks to be about 60, with her triple-D's hanging out of her ceremonial robe and everything.

She explains she's just lonely, and even though video games and the internet only carry her loneliness so far, she's been aching for real companionship. Thus, the Japanese-equivalent-of-Craigslist listing. And of course they fuck, but I'm not trying to post an entire description of how they fuck; just that it's the basis for decent erotica or doujin. Heck, maybe the NEET will learn to love going outside from this.
